ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Sometimes we went into breakout rooms to read Greek on our own.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained several insights about characteristics of each genre we read and themes such as object creation or sea voyages that persisted throughout. I certainly feel more comfortable with the theory side of discussing literature, when before I probably would have heavily relied upon grammatical and language analysis.

I read a lot of Ancient Greek literature and thought about fiction and sci-fi. In seminar discussions, we talked about truth and reality in myth, world-building in fiction, and technology's role in sci-fi. I think my Greek improved a lot during this course. Vocab and grammar quizzes were really helpful for keeping me on track.
A better grasp of Greek grammar, greater confidence reading Greek, a better understanding of different genres of Ancient Greek text.
My ability to read ancient Greek was greatly enhanced by engaging with challenging texts, and I also learned new methods for interpreting ancient texts that I hadn't considered before.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I enjoyed the class! PLV and my classmates both provided a wealth of perspectives and knowledge. I left almost every class with questions, and for me personally this is an indication that the discussion was pretty riveting. 

Personally, I did not mind that we did not place emphasis on going over grammar and syntax--the theoretical stuff was so much cooler, and I'm glad PLV was willing to sacrifice grammar review in favor of a really deep conversation on mechanical beings, for example.

The only thing I was wistful about was the gradual disappearance of labs over the course of the semester--I really enjoyed them!

Strengths: We covered a lot of ground in terms of Greek authors, going from Hesiod to Lucian.  feel like I learned a lot about ancient Greek literature just because of the variety. Also, we read lots of wacky, crazy texts like Lucian (where the characters visit the moon and fight a war there), so that was fun. The other students had so many interesting thoughts to contribute. Also, Prof. LeVen was great and fostered a really fun class environment. One last strength: I felt like the workload was not very high, especially for an L5 language class. If you want an L5 Greek class but don't want to be overwhelmed with work, this class might be a good fit.

Weaknesses: I thought the sci-fi/fiction themes of the course didn't always come through clearly to me in the texts we were reading. While the discussions were interesting, it sometimes felt like we were meandering and confusing ourselves with questions instead of getting answers. I wonder if Prof. LeVen could have jumped in more to give us more concrete observations and knowledge. Also: I have heard from my classmates (and I felt this way too) that we sometimes felt too inadequate to contribute or ask questions. I myself sometimes felt like I didn't have enough background knowledge to add anything useful to the discussion. But overall, this class was really fun and I learned a lot!!!

I really enjoyed the class discussions and the authors we discussed. I was surprised that Philostratus ended up being on the final exam that I had, and I wish that we had discussed him in class at least a bit as preparation for that (although I know the final could be on a passage we didn't talk about in class), but I never felt like we were wasting time with our discussions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the class was successful in virtual engagement. Other than the obvious disadvantages of being online, the class was pretty reminiscent of an in-person seminar.
The virtual discussion format worked very well. I thought breakout rooms were fun, too.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. It covers a lot of important Greek authors and addresses interesting questions on genre, art, storytelling modes/mechanics, and more.

Yes. The subject matter is really cool, and Prof. LeVen is great. She is really passionate about Ancient Greek and working with students. Also, this class was really memorable to me because we all became friends by the end of the semester. The most valuable things about this course, for me, were the warm class environment and the opportunity to improve my Greek.

Yes, and highly.  PLV is a delightful instructor, and the texts focused on in this course are well-selected, varied, and in some cases extremely fun to read.  The themes explored are engaging and class discussions were consistently stimulating and enjoyable.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has a strong interest in ancient literature and wants to expand their critical thinking about texts beyond the linguistic components.

extras.title:
GREK 754 01/GREK 454 01
        Greek Myth, Fiction & Sci Fi
